title: PUBLIC LIVES; Bringing a Lifetime of Faith to a Tough Job

body: Walter Isaacson is a pretty tough act to follow. For five years, the tireless managing editor of Time magazine cut a swath through magazine publishing and New York City. title: MEDIA; Time Gets A New Style At the Helm

body: Just a year ago, John Q. Adams was holding his aching head and wondering what had gone wrong. title: Brooklyn School Breaks From the Pack; A Case Study in How State Testing Was Used to Improve Education

body: THE doughboy gazes stoically through the mesh steel cage, unfazed by the clownish dent in his helmet or the bronze plaque leaning against his chest. He is surrounded by heads without pedestals, lampposts without lamps, eagles without perches. This collection of ghostly fragments of New York's past resides in a storeroom under the Triborough Bridge
title: CITY LORE; Huddled Masses of City Statuary Face Eviction

title: St. Vincents Mourns Loss Of 4 Nurses

body: Between 1990 and 1996, 794,400 immigrants settled in New York City. That's 15 per hour -- and those are only the official, documented newcomers. They did not spread out evenly across the city. Two-thirds of them settled in Brooklyn and Queens, especially in the neighborhoods of Flatbush, Bay Ridge and Astoria; another 20 percent took Manhattan,
title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00: Map: Immigration; Moving In

title: Residential Real Estate; Multiple Listings Sought For Homes in Brooklyn

title: With Fred Astaire to Emulate, Can Golf Be That Hard?

title: CITY LORE; Yes! It's Him! (Whaddya Mean, Never Heard of Him?)

title: The Pursuit of Less

title: Operator Sought for Rebuilt Brooklyn Rail Yard

title: State Senate Race Features a Rare Republican Primary

body: Joe McCarthy sees Redcoats everywhere in Brooklyn. In his mind's eye, British troops come surging by the tens of thousands off the war boats massed in the Narrows off Bay Ridge, just as they did on the humid, breezy morning of Aug. 27, 1776. They march in endless formation up Fourth Avenue, past the auto body places and worn bodegas, and pelt the
title: Red Cars, Not Coats, And a Cast Of One; Battle of Brooklyn, Evoked on a Budget

body: While the United States Senate race in New York is the biggest drawing card for the November election, several high-pitched, energetic contests are also generating a lot of interest in next month's primary. title: Lively Local Races Are Adding Zest to the Ballots of September

body: WHAT was once one of Brooklyn's most important clubs is now St. Ann's School, founded in 1965 at 129 Pierrepont Street with unconventional goals and described in its brochure as ''an amusement park'' in which the amusements include Aristophanes, Darwin and Baudelaire. title: Streetscapes/129 Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn Heights; 1906 Building, Once an Athletic Club, Now a School

body: When Frank Perri opened Buzz-A-Rama 500 in 1965, slot car racing was all the rage in New York City. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; 35 Years Later, Mr. Slot Car Remains in the Driver's Seat

title: 2 Die as Newspaper Truck Hits Police Car

body: Taste of Brooklyn www.tasteofbrooklyn.com O.K., so Brooklyn is not exactly the land of milk and honey. But there is plenty of other yummy stuff on the menu, so much that it is getting hard to keep track of it all. But don't despair. There is a Web site dedicated solely to monitoring, rating and sometimes ranting about the mushrooming restaurant
title: NEW YORK ONLINE; Brownstone Soup

body: The bagel. The knish. The pepperoni slice. To couple the words ''Brooklyn'' and ''food'' is to evoke these legendary immigrant-inspired snacks that over the last century have filled the bellies of locals and injected pizazz into palates of Americans from Memphis to Malibu. But lest anyone think Brooklyn's gastronomic glories are limited to these
title: CITY LORE; Brooklyn on 10,000 Calories a Day

title: Property Values And ZIP Codes

title: A LA CARTE; A Focus for Gutsy Salvadoran Soul Food

title: In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher

body: Joe McCarthy sees Redcoats everywhere in Brooklyn. title: Red Cars, Not Coats, And a Cast Of One; Battle of Brooklyn, Evoked on a Budget

body: Eighty-four people were hurt, three of them critically, when a subway train derailed as it pulled out of a station in downtown Brooklyn last night, hurling passengers into one another and against the train's windows, causing many head injuries, the authorities said. As the southbound B train left the DeKalb Avenue station at 9:57 p.m., the third
title: Train Derails In Brooklyn, Injuring Scores

body: ALTENAU-Grace Anna. Dr. Grace, well loved Pediatrician and long time resident of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn and Breezy Point, Queens died Friday, June 2nd, 2000 at age 91. She is survived by her son, John Holland Cassity and her daughter Adelaide VanNuys Cassity. Visitation is Wednesday, June 7 2-5 and 7-9pm at Fred Herbst Funeral Home, 7501 5th Avenue,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ALTENAU, GRACE ANNA. DR.

body: A New York Post delivery truck collided with a police car headed to a report of gunfire early yesterday morning, killing the driver of the truck and a police officer, the authorities said. The authorities described the accident as a horrendous crash. The 33,000-pound truck struck the passenger side of the police car at 3:37 a.m. at Bay Ridge
title: 2 Die as Newspaper Truck Hits Police Car

body: EVENTS Onward and Upward Regularly to be found at Avery Fisher Hall, Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic are fixtures of Manhattan's Upper West Side. But today they are going higher -- to 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, to be exact, where they will give their ninth annual free Memorial Day Concert at 8 p.m. in the Cathedral of St. John the
title: This Week

body: Taste of Brooklyn www.tasteofbrooklyn.com O.K., so Brooklyn is not exactly the land of milk and honey. But there is plenty of other yummy stuff on the menu, so much that it is getting hard to keep track of it all. But don't despair. There is a Web site dedicated solely to monitoring, rating and sometimes ranting about the mushrooming restaurant
title: NEW YORK ONLINE; Brownstone Soup

body: The bagel. The knish. The pepperoni slice. To couple the words ''Brooklyn'' and ''food'' is to evoke these legendary immigrant-inspired snacks that over the last century have filled the bellies of locals and injected pizazz into palates of Americans from Memphis to Malibu. But lest anyone think Brooklyn's gastronomic glories are limited to these
title: CITY LORE; Brooklyn on 10,000 Calories a Day

body: To the Editor: On April 2, the front-page article describing increasing property values in the five boroughs [''In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher''] indicated that the highest increase in Brooklyn was in Bay Ridge, at 8 percent to 12 percent over the last year. This was based on ZIP code analysis, which can sometimes be misleading, especially in
title: Property Values And ZIP Codes

author: E-mail address: licarte@nytimes.com
body: IF El Tazumal, a modest storefront in Glen Cove, were an Italian restaurant, it would probably be full most of the time. Although the friendly staff at this spic-and-span spot serves tasty food at rock-bottom prices, El Tazumal, at 6 Glen Street (516-674-9465), isn't Italian; it's one of an increasing number of little Latino eateries that dot the
title: A LA CARTE; A Focus for Gutsy Salvadoran Soul Food

body: YOU could call Eileen Tobin a new writer, though it would be incorrect to say she is new to writing. This is not as contradictory as it may seem. From her earliest days, she loved words, said Ms. Tobin, who is 84 and lives in Morningside Gardens, a housing complex at Broadway and 123rd Street. Once, in the first grade, she was asked to stand up and
title: NYC; Joy and Anger As a Career Takes Flight

body: NO getting away from it: everywhere in New York City home prices just keep climbing -- from the rarefied heights of Manhattan where 11 apartments have sold for $10 million or more so far this year, compared with just six in all of 1999, to every single ZIP code area in the city's other boroughs. A studio in Manhattan costs 31 percent more than it
title: In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher

body: When baseball season starts this week, a heated issue will return to the table: what wine goes with hot dogs? At home, he says, ''if the day is hot, I would have something white and chilled; a
title: WINE UNDER $20; Baseball, Hot Dogs and . . .

body: A 17-year-old Romanian immigrant from Port Washington, N.Y., who encrypted a secret message on a DNA strand won first prize and a $100,000 college scholarship today in the Intel Science Talent Search. She led two other Long Islanders in a remarkable sweep of 3 of the top 10 places in the national competition. A senior from Midwood High School in
title: Words Hidden in DNA Win Intel Competition

body: Grasping a bar designed to help blind children keep their balance as they play, 4-year-old Monique jumps up and down on a small yellow trampoline. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Blind Children Take a Small Step Toward Public School

body: FOR about a year when she was young, Maria Napoli lived in a graveyard. This was not at all disturbing to her, she recalled the other day in her cluttered, shadowy Upper West Side apartment, which she shares with her Lhasa apso, Fluffy, a dog easily mistaken for one of the pillows that threaten to crowd visitors out of the living room. title: PUBLIC LIVES; Idol of the Seventh House of Seventh Avenue

body: Pat Cetta, who with his brother, Mike, owned Sparks, a renowned New York steakhouse, died on Jan. 24. He was 66. The cause of death was a heart attack, Mike Cetta said. Sparks, at 210 East 46th Street, is the kind of clubby place where pinstriped executives can unburden themselves by removing their jackets and sticking their ties into their shirts
title: Pat Cetta, 66, the Gregarious Host of Sparks

body: McMORRIS-LeRoy Sells. Durham, NC resident, age 74, died Tuesday evening, January 25, 2000 at his home. Mr. McMorris was a veteran of the U.S. Army and the U.S. Air Force, having served during both WWII and Korea. He was retired from the City of New York where he worked as an accessibility assessor for the Mayor's Office for the Handicapped. He was
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MCMORRIS, LEROY SELLS

body: WITH the death in December of the 92-year-old sign king Douglas Leigh, the 54-year-old George Stonbely is now the grand younger man of Times Square spectaculars. Mr. Stonbely has put up a new generation of striking signs in Times Square, but like Mr. Leigh -- who was best known for his wafting Camel smoke rings -- he is always working on bigger
title: Streetscapes/George Stonbely; A Times Square Signmaker Who Loves Spectacle

body: Quick, now: If an A train leaves 207th Street and an F train leaves Coney Island, at what time will they pass in the tunnels under the Jay Street-Borough Hall station in Brooklyn -- and how many passengers will have smiled at one another, mugged one another, put on their eye makeup, finished that romance novel, thought menacing thoughts about their
title: Subway Stardom Is a Test Away; Taking the Motorman's Exam, for Money or Fantasy

body: In retrospect, it seems only natural that Paul Matus should found a Web site about the New York City transit system. He grew up in Flatbush, not far from the Church Avenue trolley, the last trolley in Brooklyn, which stopped running in 1956, when Mr. Matus was 10 years old. ''Whenever I got a good report card I would get a trolley ride,'' said Mr.
title: NEW YORK ON LINE; All About Transit, Not Only for Buffs

body: CLOSE-Mary ''Molly'' G.., 94, of Niantic, CT, died Dec. 22, 1999, at her home. Miss Close was born in London, England on September 14, 1905, the daughter of Ralph Tompkins and Margaret Godfrey Close. She grew up in Westwood, NJ and moved to Niantic in 1965. She was a graduate of Westwood (NJ) High School & Arnold College of Hygiene & Physical
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CLOSE, MARY ''MOLLY'' G.
